title: Andy Murray and Fabio Fognini kept fighting in locker room after heated on-court row
text:
The two players kept on arguing with each other long after the match had finished (Picture: Getty)

Andy Murray continued his heated argument with Fabio Fognini in the locker room after the pair had clashed on court in Tuesday’s second-round match at the Shanghai Masters.

The Brit heard a shout as he was playing a volley in the third set – which came from Fognini – and told him to ‘shut up’ as they argued at the changeover, with Murray unhappy that the umpire had not intervened.

After their back-and-forth out on the court, The Times reports that they continued to row furiously when they entered the locker room a few minutes later.

Murray snapped at Fognini to ‘shut up’ as they argued at the changeover (Picture: Getty)

Several players, coaches and officials were in the communal locker room at the time and watched on in shock as Murray and Fognini yelled at each other.

Neither player wanted to back down, with Murray furious with Fognini’s behaviour while the Italian – who has a long list of misdemeanours – laughed it off and told Murray to have a sense of humour.

The two continued to remonstrate with each other until Murray was called to his post-match press conference 15 minutes later, though still appeared agitated from their exchange.

Speaking about the altercation, he said: ‘Someone made a noise, I didn’t know who made the noise, I looked in the direction of where the noise came from.

‘He then told me, “Stop looking at me, what are you looking at me for?” I was like, “I was just about to hit a shot and someone made a noise”. He then told me to stop looking at him.

Murray, who has flown back to the UK, still looked wound up at his presser (Picture: Getty)

‘He told me to stop complaining, to have a sense of humour. I wanted to know where the sound came from and it came from him, which you’re not allowed to do.

‘It’s against the rules, it’s hindrance, you shouldn’t do it. But he said I should have a sense of humour about that but in that moment neither of us were in a joking, laughing kind of mood.

‘He [umpire Fergus Murphy] wasn’t saying anything to him. I was obviously frustrated with that. He wanted to engage with me, I probably shouldn’t have done but I’m not having him talk to me like that on the court.’
